channel.description: Recent content in CSS on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to this course about CSS or Cascading Style Sheets. It’s the language used to style websites. To give them a certain visual design and appearance.

item.title: Linking CSS & HTML
item.description: CSS cannot stand on its own. It merely styles something that already exists. As such, you need content first—something to style—and then connect the two.

item.title: The Only Syntax
item.description: Despite its size, CSS is an extremely simple language. All of it follows the same syntax! Once you learn this simple structure, you know how to write 99% of CSS.

item.title: The Basic Selectors
item.description: Before we can style anything, we first need to select the thing we want to style. This chapter explains a handful of basic selectors—the simplest ones that you’ll use the most often—so we can quickly start with actually creating designs.

item.title: Inheritance & Layers
item.description: The previous chapters explained how to select a specific element. It also taught the basic syntax for adding styles to them, although we haven’t really explored that part yet.

item.title: Values I: Units
item.description: When in school, you probably had an angry physics teacher at one point. You wrote down the answer to the question: “2”.

item.title: Values II: Colors
item.description: In a language all about (visual) design, color obviously plays a huge role. I considered leaving this for later, using only basic color names like “red” and “blue” in all my examples.

item.title: The Well-Styled Web Page
item.description: Next chapter we will finally start building an actual website and learning all the different CSS properties. As promised at the start, this will be from BIG to SMALL.

item.title: The Box Model
item.description: Previous chapter taught you that CSS views everything on the page as a box. A rectangle with a certain size and location.

item.title: Positioning
item.description: Last chapter explained how CSS boxes automatically grow, but also how you can control those dimensions (to some extent).

item.title: Columns
item.description: Previous chapters explained how to determine the size and position of one element. Usually, though, you want to do both at the same time, for multiple elements.

item.title: Flexbox
item.description: Flexbox is the next concept to learn that decides both where to place multiple elements and their size at the same time.

item.title: Grid
item.description: The introduction of the CSS grid module was a major milestone. It is extremely powerful, versatile and useful. It gives finetuned control over the size and position of all elements within the grid.

item.title: Masks & Clipping
item.description: A few chapters ago, I explained “the box model” and ways to change its dimensions. This is extremely useful … but it still looks like a box.

item.title: Filter
item.description: We’re almost done with our chapters about the biggest decisions in your design. We’ve seen how to change the dimensions of an element and its overall shape.

item.title: Transform
item.description: Last chapter mentioned we had two more properties to go that could do massive changes to your design with just one line.

item.title: Background
item.description: Over the years, the name background has become somewhat misleading. Yes, of course, these properties will help you set a background (color or image) for your CSS element.

item.title: Gradients
item.description: If you thought the examples from last chapter were crazy, you’re in for a treat. CSS natively supports creating gradients, which has been a never-ending source of tricks and creative designs ever since.

item.title: Text I
item.description: Perhaps this was the chapter you’d been waiting for. I can understand that, but hopefully you agree now that changing properties of the text is a minor change, relatively speaking.

item.title: Text II
item.description: The previous chapter introduced many basic ways to manipulate how text is displayed on your website. I glossed over one major change, however, which is … the actual font!

item.title: Border
item.description: When I explained the box model—quite some chapters ago by now—one of the four properties was the border. By default, this is invisible, which allowed me to ignore it until now.

item.title: Lists
item.description: One element that receives a lot of default styling is the list. Without doing anything, browsers will add bullets in front of items and shift them a bit to the right.

item.title: Links
item.description: Links are another element that receives quite some styling by default. When you learned HTML, you probably noticed that (hyper)links automatically get a border underneath them.

item.title: Pseudo-Classes
item.description: The word “pseudo-class” is, in my eyes, needlessly convoluted and intimidating. Its application and syntax are actually very simple.

item.title: Pseudo-Elements
item.description: Last chapter, I remarked how I found the name pseudo-classes a bit unhelpful. This chapter, however, might shed some light on why they chose that name.

item.title: Transitions & Animations
item.description: At this point in the course, you have seen pretty much every major part of CSS. You should be able to create good-looking websites with that and almost any design you envisioned.

item.title: Variables
item.description: You have written (or studied) a lot of CSS by now. And you might have noticed an annoying issue: a lot of repetition.

item.title: Advanced Selectors
item.description: At the start of this course, I mentioned that I only explained the basic selectors to you. As a quick refresher, here they are again.

item.title: Counters
item.description: We are now entering the territory of CSS functionality that you might or might not need. Depending on your designs and content, these chapters might be crucial to you … or mean nothing.

item.title: Math Functions
item.description: Let me tell you a secret. Throughout this course, you’ve already seen that CSS has many functions. Any time a syntax involved parentheses (()), you were calling some built-in CSS function.

item.title: Media Queries
item.description: Near the start of the course, I briefly mentioned the @media syntax for so-called media queries. I explained how they allow you to enable/disable CSS rules only for specific media.

item.title: Web to Print
item.description: This chapter will talk about specific CSS properties and syntax to style a page for print. These only go into effect when you visit a webpage and try to print it.

item.title: Forms & Input
item.description: Forms and input are tricky. Most of it is completely handled by browsers: their functionality, checking input validity, even what they look like.

item.title: Tables
item.description: Last chapter talked about the endless default styling of forms and input, which needs a multitude of pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements to style yourself.

item.title: Text III
item.description: You’re nearing the end of this course. This chapter just has some minor properties related to text. The next one has even more properties that only apply in very specific situations.

item.title: Interactivity
item.description: Honestly, this chapter contains the leftovers. Things that I deem important enough to explain and teach, but didn’t really belong anywhere else.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You did it! This is the final chapter in the CSS course. You’ve learned the basic syntax, most of the properties, many gotchas and practical tips for building websites.
